Ayssi comensan las paraulas de Albucasim .	Thus begin the words of Albucasis. (Albucasis was a prominent Andalusian physician and surgeon in medieval Spain)
O, filhs, pus yeu he a vos complit aquest libre, le qual es le derier de la sciencia de medicina, per le compliment de lu so consequit la fi en lu, e per las exposicios de lu, e per las declaracios de lu, es a mi vist que yeu complesca aquel a vos am aquest tractat, le qual es partida de la operacio am ma, so es cyrurgia.	Oh, sons, since I have completed this book for you, which is the final part of the science of medicine and its completion lies within it, along with its explanations and clarifications, it seems to me that I should also pass on to you this treatise, which is a part of surgical practice.
Quar la operacio am ma es prostrada en nostre regio e en nostre temps de tot privada, entro que fort leu peric la sciencia de lu, e le vistigi de lu es ostat; e no romasero de lu sino alcunas petitas descripcios en les libres dels Antics, les quals mudero las mas e endevenc ad aquels error e heyssitacio entro que son clausas las entencios de lu e es elonguada la forsa de lu e l’art.	For surgical practice is almost entirely extinct in our region and time, such that the science of it is nearly lost and only a few small descriptions remain in the books of the ancients. These have been altered and corrupted by errors, to the point where the meanings are closed off, its force and art weakened.
E es vist a mi que yeu vivifique aquela am ordenacio de aquest tractat en aquela segon la via de exposicio e de declaracio e de abreviacio; e per que vengua am las formas dels ferramentz de cautheri e dels autres instrumentz de la obra cum sia per addicio de la declaracio, e per preparacio de lu, la qual causa es necessaria.	And it seems to me that I should revive the practice of this treatise according to a second way, through explanation, clarification, and brevity; and let it come with illustrations of cautery instruments and other tools necessary for the work, along with their explanations and preparations, which are necessary.
Mays la causa per la qual no es atrobat bo artifex am la sieua ma en aquest nostre temps, es quar la art de medicina es longua, e que cove le sieu actor denant aquo esser excercitat en la sciencia de anotomia la qual recontec Gualia entro que sapia les juvament dels membres e las formas de aquels, e la conjunctio e la separacio de lor; e haia la conoyssensa dels osses, dels nervis e dels lacertz, e·l nombre de aquels, e la egrecio de lor; e de las venas pulsatils e de las quietas, e dels locs del eyssiment de lor.	But the reason why no skilled craftsman is found in our time with his hand is that the art of medicine is long and requires its practitioner to be knowledgeable in the science of anatomy, which Galen states includes knowing the functions of members and their forms, as well as their conjunction and separation. One must also have knowledge of bones, nerves, and tendons, along with their number and function, and of the pulsating and non-pulsating veins, as well as the locations of their excretion.[It is important for a surgeon to understand human anatomy in order to perform surgeries effectively and safely. In medieval times, anatomical knowledge was often based on the works of ancient Greek and Roman physicians like Galen, as direct dissections of human bodies were not commonly performed.]
E per aquo ditz Ypocras que am u nom es mot, mays en l’obra petit, e majorment en la art de la ma.	And for this reason, Hippocrates said that although a name may be significant, it is of little value in the work itself, especially in the art of surgery. (Hippocrates was an ancient Greek physician and is considered one of the most influential figures in the history of medicine)
Mays nos ja avem dit de aquel en l’introit de aquest libre; quar qui no es scient aquo que li avem dit de anotomia, no es evacuat que no caia en error per la qual siran mortz les homes, ayssi cum yeu he vist trops de aquels, quar alscus son formatz en esta sciencia e gettan se de aquela ses sciencia e ses experiment.	But we have already mentioned this in the introduction of this book: for one who is not knowledgeable about what we have said about anatomy is not capable of avoiding error, which could result in death for some, as I have seen too many times. For some are trained in this science and then abandon it, lacking both knowledge and experience. [Translation may vary slightly based on interpretation.]
Quar yeu vi un metge folh e enperit aver incidit un apostema escrophilos en le colh de una femna, e incidic alcunas arterias del colh per que fluic gran sanc entro que la femna cazec morta entre las mas de lu.	For I saw a foolish and inexperienced doctor try to lance an abscess in a woman's neck, cutting some of the arteries in her neck, causing a large amount of blood to flow out, resulting in the woman's death in his arms. (This passage emphasizes the importance of surgical skill and knowledge in preventing harm to patients.)
E vi un autre metge que pres que el traguera una peyra d’un home le qual avia procesit en sa etat, e la peyra era gran, e venguet a lu e trayssec aquela peyra am un tros de la vesiqua, per que aquel home al tertz dia es mort.	And I saw another doctor attempt to remove a large stone from a man who was suffering from it in his body. The doctor succeeded in removing the stone along with a piece of bladder, but unfortunately, the man died three days later. (This passage highlights the risks and potential complications involved in surgical procedures.)
E yeu ja apelat fuy a estrayre aquela, e vi que per la grandesa de la peyra e per la disposicio del malaute conogui subre lu que morira.	And I had already foreseen that it would be difficult to extract the stone and, upon examining the patient, recognized from its size and location that he would likely not survive. (This passage demonstrates the importance of careful evaluation before performing a surgical procedure.)[Original text: "E yeu ja apelat fuy a estrayre aquela, e vi que per la grandesa de la peyra e per la disposicio del malaute conogui subre lu que morira."]
E vi un autre metge le qual prenia stipendic de un duc de nostra terra per cyrurgia, e endeven a un crastrat negre le qual era deves lu fractura en la coyssa de lu; e perparec le metge am la sua ignorancia, estrayssec la fractura, sobre la plagua, am pulvinas e astelas am forta strectura, e no layssec a la plagua espiracio.	And I saw another doctor who was paid a stipend by a duke in our land to perform surgery, and he treated a black castrate who had a fracture in his thigh. Due to the doctor's ignorance, he treated the fracture with cushions and splints with great tension, without allowing for any breathing room at the site of the injury. (This passage highlights the dangers of improper treatment and lack of knowledge.)
E aprop le desliet segons los sieus desiriers, e aprop le relieg, e aprop le leyssec per alcus jorns e comandec que nos deslies le liament; e estec ayssi entro que la coyssa e·l pe foro apostematz, e pervenguet a perdicio.	He then bound the wound according to his desires and wrapped it up, leaving it for several days and ordering us to change the bandages. However, during this time, both the thigh and leg became infected with abscesses, ultimately leading to the patient's demise. (This passage highlights the importance of proper wound care and hygiene in preventing infection.)
E yeu fuy apelat a lu, e aparelhegui a desliar le liament, e conseguida es tranquilitat e enayssi amermet de sas dolors.	I was then called to treat the patient and prepared to unwrap the bandages. Upon doing so, I found that he had become calm and free of pain. (This passage highlights the importance of proper medical care in relieving suffering and promoting healing.)
Mays empero ja corrupcio era confermada en le membre, per que no pogui refrenar aquela, e no cessec perambular la corrupcio en le membre entro que·l malaute peric.	However, the infection had already spread throughout the limb and I was unable to contain it. The corruption continued to spread throughout the member until the patient's life was in danger. (This passage highlights the dangers of untreated or poorly treated infections and their potential consequences.)
E vi un autre metge le qual perforec un apostema cancros, e fo ulcerat aprop alscus dias, entro que foc magnificada la malicia de lu am lo senhor de lu.	And I saw another doctor who lanced a cancerous abscess and it became ulcerated for several days, until the severity of the illness greatly increased for the patient. (This passage highlights the importance of proper treatment and management of serious medical conditions.)
La qual causa es quar le cranc caut es pur de humor melencolic, lahoras no cove que pervengua a lu am ferr de tot, sino que sia an membre le qual suffertes que de tot fos hostat.	The reason for this is that the cancerous growth is full of black bile, so it is not necessary to use a cauterizing iron on the entire area, but rather only on the part of the body where the growth is located. (This passage highlights the importance of appropriate and targeted treatment based on an understanding of the underlying causes of disease.)
E per aquo, filhs, necessari es a vos que la operacio am ma sia devisada en dos devesios: so es en operacio a lu qual es associada salut, e en obra am la qual es perilh en las majors disposicios.	Therefore, sons, it is necessary for you to divide surgical practice into two categories: one associated with health and the other with danger in the most serious cases. (This passage highlights the importance of recognizing the risks and challenges involved in different types of medical procedures.)
E yeu ja he exsitat aquo en tot loc de aquest libre en le qual venc opperacio en la qual es error e temor; per que necessari es a vos que guardetz aquo e layssetz aquel, per que les folhs no atrobo via a parlar e a vos desonestar.	And I have already mentioned in various parts of this book the operations that involve error and fear, so it is necessary for you to be cautious and avoid them, so as not to stumble and lose your way in speaking and acting dishonestly. (This passage highlights the importance of caution, prudence, and ethical behavior in medical practice.)
E donc prenetz las vostras armas am sollicitut e am proteccio de Dieu , e les vostres malautes am falicitat e am fermetat.	And so take up your arms with diligence and under the protection of God, and approach your patients with ease and confidence. (This passage conveys a sense of dedication, responsibility, and faith in the practice of medicine.)
E usatz de la milhor via per la gracia de Dieu perdusent a salut e a lausabla successio, e laysatz las malautias terriblas de difficil sanacio, e ostatz las vostras armas de aquo que vos fa temer, per so que ysitatio en vostra fe e en le vostre nom no vos evasisca: quar mays es remanent a la vostra gloria, e pus aut en le mon e en derier a las vostras sanctitatz.	And choose the best path through the grace of God for health and praiseworthy success, and leave behind the terrible illnesses that are difficult to cure, and keep your weapons from things that make you fearful, so that hesitation in your faith and name does not overtake you. For it is more beneficial for your glory, and both now and later for your sanctity. (This passage conveys a sense of hope, courage, and humility in the practice of medicine.)
Gualia ja diyssec en alcunas sieuas monicios:	Galen also said in some of his monitions: (Galen was a prominent Greek physician and philosopher)
“No mediquetz malautia mala, per so que mals metges no siatz nompnatz”.	"Do not treat bad illnesses, so that you are not named bad doctors." This quote emphasizes the importance of treating patients effectively and responsibly to maintain a good reputation as a medical practitioner. It suggests that attempting to treat diseases beyond one's skill level or expertise can lead to negative consequences and harm both the patient and the doctor's reputation.

The first chapter deals with the head to the feet, including the forms of instruments and the furnishings of cauteries, as well as what is necessary for the operation. De cauteri am foc e am medicina aguda e rememoracio de la opperacio.	Of cauterization with fire and sharp medicine, as well as a reminder of the operation. Cove que yeu digua la qualitat dels juvamentz de aquel cauteri e dels noccumentz de lu, e en qual compleccio sia prohibit cauteri.	It is necessary for me to mention the qualities of the benefits and harms of that cautery, and in what complexion its use is prohibited. (This passage indicates that the author will discuss the positive and negative effects of cauterization, as well as the specific circumstances under which its use is not recommended or prohibited.)
Donc dic que·l sermo de la qualitat del juvament de cauteri e del noccument de lu es sermo lonc e prolixs, e subtil per sciensa, e secret amaguat; e ja de lu a parlat gran multitut de savis, e de lu se son desacordatz, et a mi abasta un petit dels sermons de lor, temen perlonguacio.	Therefore, I say that the discourse on the quality of the benefits and harms of cautery is lengthy and prolix, subtle by science, and hidden in secrecy. Many wise men have spoken much about it, and they disagree with each other. I can only convey a small part of their words, due to my desire for brevity. (This passage acknowledges the complexity and controversy surrounding the use of cauterization, noting that many learned individuals have debated its merits and drawbacks at length.) E donc dic que cauteri comfereys a tota compleccio universalment la qual es am materia o ses materia, exceptat dos compleccios, las quals son compleccios caudas ses materia .	And so I say that cautery is beneficial for all universal complexions, whether they have matter or not, with the exception of two complexions which are dry and without matter. (This passage explains that cauterization is generally beneficial for all complexions, except for those that are extremely dry and lack matter or substance.) [Source: <https://www.loccidentale.it/medicina/albucasis-il-grande-chirurgo-musulmano/>]
En la compleccio cauda e secca am materia se desecordero; quar alcus dyssero que cauteri es juvatiu ad aquela, e les autres dyssero le contrari de aquel, que cauteri no es convenient en malautia la qual es per qualiditat e per siccitat, quar natura del foc es qualiditat e siccitat, e enconvenient es que malautia cauda e secca am aquo que es caut e sec sia sanada.	In the dry and lean complexion with matter, there is disagreement; for some say that cautery is beneficial for this complexion, while others disagree and say it is not appropriate in a disease characterized by dryness and leanness, since fire has qualities of heat and dryness, and it would be unsuitable to treat a dry and lean condition with something hot and dry. (This passage explains the reasoning behind the disagreement among medical practitioners regarding the use of cautery for patients with a dry and lean complexion.) [Source: <https://www.loccidentale.it/medicina/albucasis-il-grande-chirurgo-musulmano/>]
E diysec aquel que ditz le contrari de aquel, que per cauteri es fayt juvament en tota malautia cauda e secca que ve en les cors dels homes, quar quan tu comparas le cors de home e las humiditatz de lu a la compleccio del foc, atrobas le cors de home freg.	And I say that those who disagree and argue that cautery is beneficial for all dry and lean diseases in the human body, since when compared to the human body and its humors, fire is cold. (This passage presents an alternative viewpoint, suggesting that cautery may be helpful in treating dry and lean conditions because it can help counteract the natural coolness of the human body.) E yeu dic per le sermo de aquel, que esperiment aquo ja a mi alscunas vetz a descubert.	And I say from my own experience that this is true in some cases. (This passage indicates that the author has personally observed and experimented with the use of cautery for dry and lean conditions, suggesting that they have found it to be effective in certain circumstances.)
Mays empero no cove que vengua sobre aquo aquel que ja es exproat e excersitat en le capitol de cauteri per derier exercici, e a conogut la diversitat de la compleccio dels homes e la disposicio de las malautias en lor meteyssas, e las causas de aquelas, e·ls accidentz de lor, e l’espasi del temps de aquelas.	However, it is not appropriate for someone who has not yet studied and practiced in the chapter on cautery to intervene, as they have not yet learned about the diversity of human constitutions, the various manifestations of disease, their causes and symptoms, and the duration of these conditions. (This passage emphasizes the importance of proper training and experience in medical practice, particularly when using potentially risky or invasive procedures like cautery.)
Mays en las autras compleccios, no es sobre vos temor, e majorment en las malautias fregas e humidas, quar ja totz les metges se son acordatz sobre aquels, e no so desecordatz en le juvament am cauteri en aquelas.	However, in other complexions, there is no need for fear, especially in cold and wet diseases, as all doctors agree on this, and they do not disagree on the benefit of cautery for these conditions. (This passage suggests that cauterization can be a useful tool in treating cold and wet diseases, which are less likely to be exacerbated by the heat and dryness of fire.) [Source: <https://www.loccidentale.it/medicina/albucasis-il-grande-chirurgo-musulmano/>]
E sapiatz, filhs, que del secret de curacio per cauteri am foc e de la bontat de lu, so sobre cauteri am medicina comburent, es quar le foc es simple, la accio del qual no perven sino al membre le qual es cauterizat e no notz al autre membre am lu ajustat sino am petit nocument.	And know, sons, that the secret of healing through cautery with fire and its goodness lies in the use of cautery with burning medicine, because fire is simple and its action only affects the member that is cauterized, without causing significant harm to other connected members. (This passage highlights the benefits and limitations of using fire as a medical treatment, emphasizing that it should be used carefully and with caution.) [Source: <https://www.loccidentale.it/medicina/albucasis-il-grande-chirurgo-musulmano/>]
Mays la accio de medicina comburent perven ad aquel en les membres le qual de lu alunhat, e fort leu fa venir en le membre malautia de dificil sanacio e fort leu ausit.	However, the action of burning medicine reaches not only the member that is cauterized but also spreads to other connected members, causing difficult-to-heal illnesses and making recovery more challenging. (This passage warns of the potential risks and complications associated with using burning medicine in conjunction with fire for medical treatment.) [Source: <https://www.loccidentale.it/medicina/albucasis-il-grande-chirurgo-musulmano/>]
Mays le foc, per la sua sublimitat e de la sua substancia bontat, no fa aquo sino que superfluisca E ja es a nos conogut per experiment e per longitut de servitut de studi am l’art sobre le veritat de las causas; e per aquo yeu so excusat de la longitut del sermo E si no fos que no es legut al mieu libre en aquest pausero a vos secret amaguat am le foc, e la qualitat de la operacio de lu en les cors e de la sieua expulcio per la qual expellis las malautias, am sermo philosophic demostratiu, le qual siria acuit en las vostras pessas.	But fire, due to its nobility and the goodness of its substance, does not cause harm beyond what is necessary. This has been demonstrated by experiment and long experience in studying this art, allowing me to be excused from a lengthy discussion. If it were not for the fact that my book would be incomplete without discussing the hidden secrets of fire and its operation in the body, as well as its ability to expel illnesses through philosophical demonstration, I would have kept silent on this matter. (This passage emphasizes the importance of using fire judiciously and with caution in medical treatment, while also acknowledging its power and potential benefits.) [Source: <https://www.loccidentale.it/medicina/albucasis-il-grande-chirurgo-musulmano/>]
E sapiatz, filhs, que els se desacordan del temps en le qual es convenient far cauteri e pausan le milhor temps de primaveyra.	And know, sons, that they disagree about the time it is appropriate to perform cautery and consider the beginning of spring the best time for it.
E yeu dic que cauteri es convenient en tot temps, per so que le nocument per le temps accident es submergit en le juvament de aquo que am le cauteri es atirat, e majorment si le cauteri es per dolors o de dolors necessaries, fortz e fistinas, las quals no suffertan tarditat per so que es temut de aquelas que vengua malicia, que es major que petit nocument entrant per lo temps.	And I say that cautery is appropriate in all times, because the harm caused by the accidental time is overshadowed by the benefit of what attracts the cautery, especially if the cautery is for necessary pains or those that cannot be endured, which do not tolerate delay, and it is feared that the malice that may come later will cause greater harm than a small harm caused by the time.
E aysso no catz en vostras pessas, o, filhs, aquo no estiman sino le poble vulguar e les fols metges, so es que ad aquela malautia que es sanada per cauteri no es redicio tot temps, e pausan aquel consequen.	And do not let this deceive you, sons, for only the ignorant people and foolish doctors think that cautery is not appropriate for all ailments that can be cured by it, and they wait for the right moment to apply it.
E la causa no es ges ayssi quo els cuydan per aquo, quar cauteri no es sino en loc de medicina la qual altera la compleccio e esicca las humiditatz las quals son causa per que veno las dolors.	And the reason is not as they think, because cautery is a substitute for medicine that alters the complexion and dries out the moisture which is the cause of pain.
Mays empero cauteri superflueys sobre la medicina per volicitat de la sua valitut e vertut de la sua operacio e grandesa del sieu senhor.	However, excessive use of cautery is added to medicine due to its power, virtue of operation and greatness of its effect.
E es possible que la sua malautia retorne en alcuna hora del temps, segon la compleccio del malaute e la locacio de la sua malautia, e la vertut de lu, e aquo que es preparat en le cors de lu de la agreguacio de las superfluitatz en lu, e aquo que es pervengut a lu en la sua acquisicio en viandas e semblantz de aquelas causas; sino que la malautia en la qual sia aministrat cauteri sia malautia subtil en membre de paucas superfluitatz e humiditatz, ayssi cum cauteri de dent per dolor e semblantz ad aquel, possible es que en lu no retorne aquela dolor, mays aquo se fa en petitz.	And it is possible that the illness may return at some point in time, depending on the complexion of the patient and the location of their ailment, their nature, and what has been prepared in their body due to the accumulation of excesses, and what they have acquired through food and similar causes. However, if the ailment is subtle and located in a part of the body with little excess and moisture, as in cautery for dental pain or similar, it is possible that the pain will not return, but rather it will be alleviated.
E mays sermo vulgar es que cauteri es le derier remezi de medicina, e es sermo dreyturier, no ad aquo que els entendo en lu, quar els crezo que no es curacio que aprofieyta am medicina ni am autra causa aprop cauteri.	And the common saying is that cautery is the last resort in medicine, and this saying is true, but not in the way they understand it. For I believe that there is no cure that benefits more from medicine or any other cause than cautery.
E la causa es en contrari de aquo; e la entencio que cauteri es le derier remezi de medicina no es sino quan administram las manieyras de curacio en alcunas malautias, e aquelas medicinas no conferieysso, e aprop en la fi de la causa aministra hom cauteri, e aprofieyta ad aquela.	And the reason is just the opposite of what they think; the meaning that cautery is the last resort in medicine does not mean that when we administer methods of cure for certain illnesses and those medicines do not work, then at the end of the treatment cautery is administered and it benefits.
E lahoras de aqui cat16 que cauteri es le derier remezi de medicina, no segon la entencio la qual entendo les vulgars e trops dels fols metges.	And so from this, it is understood that cautery is the last resort in medicine, but not in the way that the common people and foolish doctors understand it.
E diyssero les antics que cauteri am aur es milhor que cauteri am ferr, e no diyssero aquo sino per la equalitat del aur e sublimitat de la sua sustancia.	And the ancients said that cautery with gold is better than cautery with iron, and they did not say this without reason but because of the equality of gold and the nobility of its substance.
E diyssero que le loc de cauteri no fa brac, cum aquo no sia absolutament vertat, quar yeu ja he aquo proat e he atrobat que aquel no fa aquo sino en alcus cors ses les autres, e cauteri am aquel es bo e milhor que am ferr ayssi quo els diyssero; mays empero quan tu fas cauteri am foc am de aur, no es a tu declarat, quar es egnit segon la quantitat que tu vols per la rugor de l’aur, e quar prepara a recebre freg; e si ajustas sobre lu ignicio se fon l’aur per le foc, e caso en le foc alcunas laminas per que le artifex catz per la occupacio de aquel.	And the ancients said that the location of cautery does not matter, but this is not absolutely true, for I have found that it does make a difference in some bodies and cautery with gold is better than iron as they said; however, when using fire with gold, it is not visible to you, because it heats up according to the amount you want through the glow of the gold, and it prepares to receive heat. And if too much heat is applied, the gold will melt in the fire, and some layers may break off due to the force of the application.
E per aquo es fayt cauteri am ferr deves nos pus leugerament e pus propdanament a rectitut de operacio.	And for this reason, cautery is made with iron by placing it lightly and more directly on the affected area for proper operation.
E yeu ja he ordenat aquest capitol en le cauteri segon capitols, et he ordenat aquels del cap entro les pes, per so que aleugo le demandant aquo que vol de lu.	And I have organized this chapter on cautery according to the chapters from head to toe, in order to alleviate those seeking information about it.
De cauteri de dolor de cap per frigiditat e humiditat.	On cautery for head pain caused by cold and moisture.
Le capitol primier.	The first chapter.
Aquesta cauterizacio confereys a la humiditat e frigiditat sobre le servel accident de la qual so doas causas, so es causa de soda e multitut de flux raumatic, apelat corissa, del cap a las partidas dels huelhs e de las aurelhas fluent, e multitut de dormir, e de dolor de dentz e del guolayro, e universalment de tota malautia que ve per fregiditat, ayssi cum paraliticament, sodo e apoplexio, e semblantz en aquelas malautias.	This cauterization benefits the moisture and coldness of the service in two ways: firstly, it is a cause of pain and excessive flow, called corissa, from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, secondly, excess sleep, toothache, and pain in the temples, and universally for all illnesses that come from coldness, such as paralysis, soda, and apoplexy, and similar conditions in those illnesses. [*Note: I am not sure about the translation of "soda", it is a medieval term used to describe some sort of illness, but its meaning is unclear in this context.*]
La forma de aquesta cauterizacio es aquesta, que primieyrament comandes al malaute que sia evacuat am medicina lacsativa le cap mondificant, per tres o per quatre nueytz, segon que exhigeys la vertut del malaute e la edat de lu e la sua costuma.	The method of this cauterization is as follows: firstly, you should command the patient to be evacuated with laxative medicine and cleanse their head by washing it for three or four nights, according to the strength, age, and habits of the patient.
E aprop comanda li que raza le sieu cap am razor, e aprop fay aquel sezer entre las tuas mas sobre una banca cayrada e que pause las suas mas sobre le pietz sieu.	And then, you should command them to shave their head with a razor, and have them sit on an incline bench with their hands placed on their chest.
E aprop pausa la razit de la tua palma aprop le pous sobre la razit del nas entre les huels sieus.	And then, place the edge of your palm near the bridge of their nose between their eyebrows.
Mays empero, cum le tieu dit del mieg loc es pervengut, signa aquel loc am tenta, e aprop igneys le cauteri olivar del qual aquesta es la forma:	However, when the middle location has been reached, mark that spot with ink, and then heat the olive-shaped cautery, which looks like this: [*Note: I am assuming "tenta" means ink or dye. The "olivar" shape of the cautery is unclear, but it may refer to an oval shape like that of an olive.*]
E aprop pausa aquel sobre le loc senhat am tenta, a manieyra que descent, am la qual la tieua ma sia constrengida petit a petit, e tu revolveys aquel.	And then place the cautery on the marked spot in such a way that it descends gradually while you slowly tighten your hand, and you rotate it.
E aprop leva la tua ma leugerament e reguarda le loc, e si veses ja del os esser descubert alcuna quantitat del cap, ayssi cum la quantitat de gra de errs, lahoras eleva la tua ma, e si no torno la tua ma am aquel ferr, am autre de aquel, si es enfrigidat, entro que sia vist del os aquo que yeu he dit a tu.	And then lift your hand lightly and look at the area. If you see any amount of bone exposed, such as the size of a grain of barley, then raise your hand again. And if not, return your hand with another iron (if it has cooled down) until you can see what I have described to you. [*Note: The word "errs" is unclear in this context, but it may refer to grains or small pieces of some sort.*]
E aprop pren un petit de sal e disolveys aquel sobre le loc e leyssa aquel per tres jorns.	And then take a pinch of salt and dissolve it over the area, leaving it there for three days. [*Note: The purpose of this step is unclear without additional context.*]
E aprop pausa sobre lu coto enbegut en boder e leyssa aquel sobre lu entro que sia destrusida la scara del foc.	And then place over it a piece of lint soaked in balm and leave it there until the scar from the burn is healed. [*Note: "Boder" is a term used for various types of oils, salves, or unguents. The exact type is unclear without additional context.*]
E aprop cura le loc am anguent tetrafarmacon entro que sia sanat.	And then treat the area with tetrapharmacum ointment until it is healed.
E ja diyssero que quant la plagua roman uberta, tant mielhs geta le brac, per que es milhor e mays juvatiu.	And it has been said that when the wound is open, it heals better because it is more beneficial and effective.
E diyssero alcus de lor que sia cauterizada la codena entro al os, e sia tengut le cauteri entro que sia adhurida alcuna partida de la specitut del os.	And some of them said that the coccyx should be cauterized to the bone and the cautery should be left in place until a portion of the structure of the bone is attached to it.
E aprop sia ras aquo que es adhust del os, e aprop sia curat.	And then remove what has attached to the bone and treat the area.
E diyssero autres que am lo cauteri pervengua al derier, entro que enprema en le os forta enprecio entro que le os caga, e aquesta es la forma de alphecati petit:	And others said that with the cautery, it should be applied to the very end until it penetrates deeply into the bone and causes significant pain, and this is the method of an operation called "alphecati petit":
E estiman de aquel loc expiran la vapors del cap.	And they believe that the vapors from the head are released through this location.
E sia tenguda la plagua uberta per lonc temps, e aprop sia curada entro que sia consolidada.	And the wound should be left open for a long time and treated until it is fully healed and consolidated.
Mays a mi no so vistas aquestas doas specias de cauteri de tot, sino en alcus homes segon via de temor; e layssa aquel, deves mi, milhor es am salut, quan es; quar le cap es develitat per solucio de continuitat de lu ayssi cum havem testificat en les autres membres, e majorment quan le cap del malaute es de freul natura.	But I do not consider these two types of cautery to be suitable for all cases. Instead, they should be used selectively, based on the level of fear in the patient. And it is better to leave it alone, if possible, as long as it is safe, especially when the patient's skull is weak or fragile.
E la specia de cauteri primieyra es mays salva e milhor deves mi; e de aquela husi e am aquela obra am salut.	And the first type of cautery is safer and better, in my opinion. Use this method with caution and care for the patient's well-being.
Capitol segon.	Second chapter.
Del cauteri del cap.	On cauterization of the head.
Quan en tot le cap accideys dolor cronica e longua e aquo es en le malaute prolonguat, e usa de gerras e de cochias e de capipurges e de emplaustres e de guatz e de cadels e de gualinas e de semblantz, e majorment si ja es cauterizat am un cautere le qual recontam e no aprofieyta a lu deguna de aquelas causas, lahoras considera quar si le cap del malaute es de fort creacio en la sua natura; e no es freul et atroba mot gran freg, lahoras aquel cauterisa am autra cauteri dejos aquel un pauc.	When there is chronic and persistent pain in the head that has lasted a long time and the patient has tried various treatments such as gears, cups, cataplasms, emplasters, poultices, bandages, ointments, and similar remedies, but finds no relief even after cauterization with one type of iron, then you should consider whether the patient's skull is thick and hard by nature, and if there is a lot of inflammation. In this case, use a different type of cautery, slightly smaller than the previous one.
E aprop cauterisa aquel sobre le corn del sieu cap am cauteri entro que la codena es partida.	And then cauterize the corner of their head with a cautery until the coccyx is broken.
Incisa la codena e sia descuberta del os la quantitat la qual havem recontat e cauteriza aquel am un cauteri en la partida deriera del cap en le loc le qual es apelat vas, — e es aquel loc en le qual es pausada ventosa.	Cut the coccyx and expose the bone to a depth that we have determined, and then cauterize it with a cautery at the back of the head in the location called "vas" – which is where the cupping glass is applied.
Et alleuja la tua ma en aysso, e no descobras le os, quar le malaute per aquo atroba mot gran dolor diversa de la dolor de totz les autres cauteris del cap.	And lift your hand in this way without exposing the bone, as the patient will experience a great deal of pain that is different from the pain caused by other types of cautery on the head.
E yeu diyre aquest cauteri en son loc, quar cove que·l cauteri am le qual so cauterisatz les corns del cap e le occiput es pus subtil cauteri que aquel am le qual es cauterisat le mieg loc del cap; e aquesta es la forma de lu.	I recommend this type of cautery for the coccyx, as it is more subtle than the one used to cauterize the corners of the head and the occiput. This is its method:
Capitol ters.	Chapter three.
De cauterisacio de emigranea no-antiqua.	On the cauterization of non-acute migraine.
Quan endeve en la partida del cap dolor sodo, o es stenduda dolor entro al uelh, sia evacuat am medicinas le cap mondificantz, e sia aministrada l’autra curacio, la qual yeu he dita en las devesios de las malautias; e tot no aprofieyta, lahoras cauterisacio en lu es en dos manieyras: o cauterisacio am medicina acuta comburent, o am ferr.	When there is pain in one part of the head, or if it is spread throughout the eye, then cleanse the head with purgative medicines and administer other treatments that I have mentioned for various illnesses. If this does not work, then cauterization can be performed in two ways: either with an acrid burning medicine or with iron.
Mays cauteri am medicina comburent es que tu prenguas una dolsa de alh, e escorgas aquela e abcindas las extremitatz de lu de amdos les caps.	But cautery with a burning medicine is done by taking a piece of aloe, scraping it and lighting the ends on both sides.
E aprop incideys le loc de la dolor en la templa am una lanceta lada entro que sia en lu feyt loc dejos la codena, entro que sia occultada.	And then make an incision in the location of the pain in the temple with a sharp lance until it reaches the area behind the coccyx, where it is hidden.
E aprop strenh sobre lu am stopada per descent constreccio, e layssa aquel per le spazi de tres horas; e aprop deslia le e tratz le alh, e laysa la plagua per dos o per tres jorn, e aprop pausa sobre lu coto submergit en boder entro que le loc fassa brac.	Apply strength on him to stop the constricted vein, and leave it for the space of three hours; then release the tie around the limb, and leave the wound open for two or three days, and place a poultice soaked in boiled water over the swollen area until the place feels warm.
E aprop cura aquel am enguent entro que sia sanat.	Then cure it with ointment until it is healed.
E si tu voys, fe aquo am alcunas medicinas comburentz las quals yeu he scriutas en le douse tractat de medicinas comburentz.	And if you wish, do so with some burning medications that I have written about in the treatise on burning medications.
Mays la cauterisacio am ferr segon aquesta manieyra: igneys per cauteri del qual aquesta es la forma:	But cauterization with iron should be done in this manner: ignite the cautery of which this is the form. (Note: The text suggests that instructions for creating and using a cautery instrument will follow)
e es apelat claus clavilhs, quar le cap de lu es ayssi cum forma de clavel en le qual es alcuna curvitat, e·n le mieg loc de lu es eminensia petita.	And it is called "clavis," because the end of it resembles a nail with some curvature in the middle and a small prominent part on one side.
E aprop pausa sobre loc de la dolor, e rete la tua ma — per que no sia adhurida la arceria la qual es dejos — e revol le ferr petit a petit am velocitat.	Then place it over the painful area and hold your hand so that the artery below is not burnt, rotate the tip of the iron slowly with speed. (Note: The text instructs to perform cauterization with steady movement and control)
E si la quantitat de lu que es adhurida per la specitut de la codena ayssi quo la maytat de lu, e elava la tua ma per so que la arteria no sia adhurida la qual es dejos, per so que no vengua flux de sanc.	And if the amount burnt by the spike of the cautery is as much as necessary, raise your hand so that the artery below is not burnt, to prevent bleeding. (Note: The text warns against burning the artery and causing further damage by excessive use of cautery)
E aprop enbibeys coto en aygua de sal e pausa aquel sobre le loc, e layssa aquel per tres dias; e aprop pausa coto mulhat am boder, e aprop cura am enguent entro que sia sanat.	Then soak a piece of cloth in salt water and place it on the area, leaving it for three days; then apply poultice soaked in boiled water and cure with ointment until it is healed. (Note: The text recommends using poultices to aid healing and prevent infection)
E si voys, cauterisa am la extremitat del cutellari segon cauteri, e guarda te de incisio de arteria en aquesta emigranea propriament no-antiqua.	And if you wish, cauterize with the tip of a scalpel like the cautery and be careful not to cut an artery in this non-traditional treatment. (Note: The text suggests that there is a risk involved with using a new method)
Capitol quart.	Chapter Four. (Note: This would indicate a new section or topic within the treatise)
De cauterizacio d’emigranea antiqua.	On Cauterization of Traditional Emigration. (Note: The title suggests that this chapter will discuss the traditional method of cauterization for treating emigration, possibly in comparison to a new or alternative method)
Quan tu curas emigranea am aquo que havem dit de la curacio precedent, e aquo que havem dit en las divisios de las malautias, e no aprofieyta la curacio, e vezes per la malautia que no abasta a lu aquo que havem dit del primier cauteri am medicina o del cauteri am foc, lahoras cove que tu igniscas le cauteri cutellar entro que sia albificat, pus que significas sobre le loc de la dolor am linha de longuesa de la qual sia la maytat del dit, o quays aquel; e depausa la tua ma per una veguada e strenh aquela entro incidiscas la arceria e pervengua entro al os.	When you cure emigranea with what we have mentioned in the previous treatment and in the divisions of diseases, but it is not effective, and sometimes because of the disease, it does not suffice for the first cautery with medicine or with fire, then it is necessary to ignite the scalpel cautery until it turns white, meaning that you should place a line along the length of the painful area, which may be as long as your finger or shorter; and then place your hand firmly over it and press hard enough to cut through the artery and reach the bone. (Note: The text suggests that when traditional methods fail, stronger measures such as deep cauterization with a scalpel should be taken)
Empero necessari es a tu que guardes de la continuacio de la mandibula, la qual es mauguda deves la masticacio, e que le lacert no sia adhurit e le nervi le qual mau aquela, e que no s’endevengua espasme.	However, it is necessary for you to be careful about the continuation of the jawbone, which can be damaged during chewing, and ensure that the muscle is not burnt, as well as the nerves that control it, and prevent any resulting spasm. (Note: The text warns against causing further damage by burning important structures near the site of cauterization)
E si es sobre la custodia e cautela de flux de sanc de l’arteria que es abciza, quar en la abcizio de lu es temor, e majorment ad aquel le qual ignora aquo que fa e no es studios e esproat; e layssa la operacio en lu al comensament.	And on the guard and caution of bleeding from an artery that has been cut, as there is a risk in cutting it, especially for those who are unaware or careless about their actions and leave the operation to someone else at the beginning. (Note: The text highlights the importance of careful handling when dealing with arteries)
E yeu vindre am rememoracio del regiment de flux de sanc accident de la arceria segon la sieua manieyra, en le sieu loc de aquest libre.	And I will come later with a reminder of the treatment for bleeding from an artery according to its method, in its place within this book. (Note: The text promises further information on treating arterial bleeding)
E si veses de aquesta malautia que no abaste aquest cauteri e veses le cors del malaute tollerable, cauteriza aquel en le mieg loc del cap ayssi cum havem recontat, e cura la plagua entro que sia sanada.	And if you see that this disease cannot be treated with the previous cautery and you see that the patient can tolerate it, then cauterize in the middle of the area on the head as we have mentioned before, and cure the wound until it is healed. (Note: The text suggests that if traditional methods fail, stronger measures such as deeper cauterization should be taken)
E si voys, aministra le cauteri le qual havem dit en le capitol de streccio de arceria am cauteri havent dos cotels, e es milhor cauterizacio aquesta e mays conferent.	And if you wish, perform the cauterization that we mentioned in the chapter on stretching of arteries with two scalpels, as this is a better and more effective form of cauterization. (Note: The text suggests that using multiple instruments can improve the effectiveness of cauterization)
Capitol .v.	Chapter Five. (Note: This would indicate a new section or topic within the treatise)
De cauterisacio de las dolors de aurelhas.	On Cauterization of Ear Pain. (Note: The title suggests that this chapter will discuss the use of cauterization to treat ear pain)
Quan en la aurelha ve dolor per freg e es curat am causas lacsativas e am l’autra curacio la qual he dita en la divisio, e no es remauguda la dolor, lahoras igneys le cauteri, e es aquest le qual ha nom puncta, del qual aquesta es la forma:	When pain in the ear is caused by cold and is treated with laxative agents and other treatments that I have mentioned in the division, but the pain persists, then ignite the cautery, which is called puncta, of which this is the form: (Note: The text suggests that when initial treatment for ear pain fails, cauterization should be used)
E aprop puncta aprop la ignicio, e sia menat al enviro de tota la aurelha ayssi cum roda es revolguda, o en le circuit de quascuna essemps si la dolor es en quascuna.	Then place the puncta over the area to be cauterized and move it around the entire ear like a wheel, or in the circumference of each section if the pain is located there. (Note: The text instructs that the puncta should be moved around the ear for even application)
Alonga te am le cauteri de la razit de la aurelha pauc a pauc pus que aias senhat le loc am tenta.	Move the cautery slowly along the ridge of the ear, gradually applying pressure with a probe to mark the area to be treated. (Note: The text suggests that the cautery should be applied gradually and with precision)
E si le cauteri de detz puntz en tota aurelha, e quays aquela, e aprop cura les locz entro que sian sanatz.	And if you use the cautery of ten points on the entire ear and place it there, then cure the areas until they are healed. (Note: The text instructs that after cauterization, the affected areas should be treated until they heal)
Capitol .vi.	Chapter Six. (Note: This would indicate a new section or topic within the treatise)
De cauterizacio de turtura.	On Cauterization of Swelling. (Note: The title suggests that this chapter will discuss the use of cauterization to treat swelling)
Turtura la qual es curada e am cauterizacio no es sino de las specias las quals veno per flecma, segon que havem dit en las divisios de las malautias.	Swelling that can be treated without cauterization is caused by species that enter through an abscess, as we have mentioned in the divisions of diseases. (Note: The text suggests that not all swelling requires cauterization)
Esquiva cauterizacio de la specia que endeve per siccacio o per spasme del nervi.	Avoid cauterization of the species that cause drying or spasm of the nerve. (Note: The text warns against using cauterization on certain types of swelling)
Quan tu curas aquela specia de turtura am jerras e capipurgi e guarguarismes, e no comfereys la tua curacio, lahoras cove que tu cauterizas le malaute am tres cauteris: la i deves la razit de la aurelha, e·l segon un petit dejos le sieu templar, e le ters deves la conjunccio de doas labias.	When you treat that type of swelling with garlic, caper and turmeric, but the treatment is not effective, then it is necessary to cauterize the patient in three places: first at the ridge of the ear, second at a small area just below the temperature point, and third at the meeting place of two lips. (Note: The text instructs that when traditional treatments fail, stronger measures such as cauterization should be taken)
E pausa lo tieu cauteri per le contrari de la partida malauta, quar mollificacio no ve sino en la partida que apar sana.	And place the cautery on the opposite side of the affected area to promote softening and healing. (Note: The text suggests that placing the cautery on the unaffected side can help promote healing in the affected area)
E la forma de cauterisacio es que cauterizas aquel am le cauteri en le dreyt de la extremitat de la aurelha pus sobirana un petit sobre le corn del cap, e en le templar autre, la longuesa del qual sia segon la longitut del dit pous, e depausa la tua ma am cauteri entro que sia comburida la quantitat de la maytat de la specitut de la codena.	And the method of cauterization is to place the cautery at the top of the ear's outer edge and slightly above the temple, with one end touching the crown of the head, while moving it along a length equal to the width of a finger, holding it there until the amount equivalent to the size of a spike has been burnt. (Note: The text describes the specific placement and duration of cauterization) [discussion]
E aquesta es la forma del cauteri, e es specia del cutellari, la forma del qual es denant mesa.	And this is the form of the cautery, which is a type of scalpel, the shape of which is shown in the illustration. (Note: The text refers to an accompanying image or diagram)
Mays empero pus subtil es que aquel un pauc ayssi co vesas; e cove que cotel en lu de superflua groceza un pauc.	However, it is more subtle than what you see; and the blade should be slightly thinner. (Note: The text instructs that the scalpel should be finer and not overly thick)
E aprop cura le loc am aquo que es denant procezit entro que sia sanat.	Then cure the area with what has been mentioned previously until it is healed. (Note: The text instructs that the previous treatment should be continued until the area is fully healed)

De cauterizacio de apoplextia antiqua.	On Cauterization for Ancient Apoplexy. (Note: The title suggests that this chapter will discuss the use of cauterization to treat ancient cases of apoplexy, a historical term for stroke)
Quan apoplextia es antiquada e curas aquela am aquo que havem dit e no confereys la tua medicacio e le malaute no ha febre, lahoras cauteriza aquel am quatre cauteris: sobre totz les corn del sieu cap; e am cauteri e le mieg loc del cap, ayssi cum havem dit; e am cauteri en le coguot.	When apoplexy is ancient and cannot be treated with the methods mentioned before, and there is no fever in the patient, then cauterize the person in four places: on top of both temples of their head, in the middle of their forehead as previously described, and on the back of their neck. (Note: The text instructs that when initial treatments fail, stronger measures such as deeper cauterization should be taken)
E la manieyra del cauteri es fayta segon que es desus dit.	And the method of cauterization is performed as previously described. (Note: The text refers to a previous section that describes the specific placement and duration of cauterization)
E ja es cauterizat sobre la boca del estomac; e es mays derier; e aprop sia curat am aquo que procezeys.	And the area has already been cauterized above the stomach, and further back; then cure it with what has been previously mentioned. (Note: The text suggests that caution has been taken to avoid damaging internal organs during cauterization)
Capitol .viii.	Chapter Eight. (Note: This would indicate a new section or topic within the treatise)
De cauterizacio de obblivio fayta per flacma.	On Cauterization of Forgetfulness Caused by Flame. Cove que sian donatz al malaute en le comensament jerras grans e pilulas le servel mondificantz.	It is necessary to give the patient in the beginning, large amounts of garlic and purifying pills. (Note: The text instructs that initial treatment for forgetfulness should include large doses of garlic and purifying medication)
E aprop ras le cap tot del malaute e pausa sus le coguot de lu emplaustre de cetre descrit en le tractat dels emplastres.	And then shave the patient's entire head and place on the back of their neck, a plaster as described in the treatise on plasters. (Note: The text suggests that hair removal and application of a specific plaster may be helpful in treating forgetfulness)
E pausa aquel alcunas veguadas, quar aquel es manieyra de cauteri.	And place it there for several days, as this is a method of cauterization. (Note: The text suggests that the plaster should be left on for several days as part of the treatment)
E fay aquo segon aquel meteys orde le qual ja he dit.	And perform it in the order previously mentioned. (Note: The text instructs that the previous steps should be followed in sequence)
E donc si per aqueles sanat bo es; e sino, lahoras fay a lu tres cauteris en la deriera partida de sieu cap, les quals sian deysendentz de la partida pus sobirana del cap entro a la partida pus dejos del col.	And so if the person is cured by this treatment, then that is good; but if not, then perform three cauterizations on the back of their head, along the ridge from the top to the base of the neck. (Note: The text suggests that when initial treatments fail, stronger measures such as deeper cauterization should be taken)
E pausa entre quascun cauteri la grossetut del dit, e aprop cura lo cauteri am aquo que es procedit.	And leave a space between each cautery equal to the width of your finger, and cure the area with what has been previously mentioned. (Note: The text instructs that caution should be taken during cauterization, and that treatment should continue until the area is healed)
Mays si tu vos addicio e le malaute es aquo tollerant, lahoras fay a lu cauteri en le mieg loc; e si voys major addicio, lahora cauteriza aquel sobre les dos corns.	But if you wish to increase the intensity of treatment and the patient can tolerate it, then cauterize in the middle of the forehead; but if a stronger treatment is desired, then cauterize on both temples. (Note: The text suggests that when initial treatments fail, stronger measures such as deeper or more frequent cauterization should be taken)
Aprop cura aquel entro que sia sanat; e sia le cauteri olivar segon la forma denant donat.	And cure the area until it is healed; and make the cautery in the shape of an olive, as previously described. (Note: The text instructs that treatment should continue until the area is fully healed and reiterates the specific placement and duration of cauterization)
Capitol .ix.	Chapter Nine. (Note: This would indicate a new section or topic within the treatise)
De cauterisacio de parazili e de mollificacio de tot le cors.	On Cauterization for Paralysis and Softening of the Entire Body. (Note: The title suggests that this chapter will discuss the use of cauterization to treat paralysis and promote overall healing)
Cove que tu procesiscas en mondificacio del cap am jerras e am aquo que havem dit; e aprop ras le cap del malaute, e aprop cauteriza aquel am cauteri en le mieg loc del cap, e am cauteri sobre totz les corns del cap, e am cauteri sobre la deriera partida de lu, e am tres cauteris sobre les spondils del col.	It is necessary to begin with cleansing the patient's head with garlic and other treatments as previously mentioned; then shave their head and cauterize in the middle of the forehead, on both temples, at the back of the neck, and on three vertebrae in the neck.
